content:
TextBlock(citations=None, text='<result>
Based on the information found, the key differences in COVID-19 severity between men and women were:

- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher levels of procalcitonin (an inflammation marker) compared to women with severe COVID-19.
- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher BMI and C-reactive protein levels compared to men with moderate COVID-19.
- Women with severe COVID-19 had higher INR levels (a blood clotting measure) and longer hospital stays compared to women with moderate COVID-19.

Overall, the data suggests that while both men and women experienced more severe COVID-19 illness as they got older, there were some gender-specific differences in certain biomarkers and clinical outcomes. Men tended to have higher inflammation levels, while women had more issues with blood clotting and longer hospital stays.
</result>', type='text')

final_output_text:
<result>
Based on the information found, the key differences in COVID-19 severity between men and women were:

- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher levels of procalcitonin (an inflammation marker) compared to women with severe COVID-19.
- Men with severe COVID-19 had higher BMI and C-reactive protein levels compared to men with moderate COVID-19.
- Women with severe COVID-19 had higher INR levels (a blood clotting measure) and longer hospital stays compared to women with moderate COVID-19.

Overall, the data suggests that while both men and women experienced more severe COVID-19 illness as they got older, there were some gender-specific differences in certain biomarkers and clinical outcomes. Men tended to have higher inflammation levels, while women had more issues with blood clotting and longer hospital stays.
</result>
